Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Post-eruption reinflation at Axial Seamount
Award.AbstractNarration:
Axial Seamount is an active submarine volcano on the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the NE Pacific that erupted in 1998 and 2011, and is currently inflating in a way that suggest renewed magma injection below the seafloor. This recent activity provides access to study the dynamic interactions between seafloor volcanism, hydrothermal venting, and biological responses. Axial is the first and only site in the world where a volcanic deformation cycle has been documented on the seafloor and it will soon have operating sensors and real-time data transmission as part of the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI). Being able to forecast possible future magmatic activity based on recent seafloor deformation, and associated inferences on magma injection, may help guide OOI science planning.

Continued monitoring of seafloor depth changes will document vertical deformation associated with magmatic inflation/deflation at Axial Seamount. A combination of Bottom Pressure Recorders, which provide continuous data, and campaign-style reoccupation of existing benchmarks will quantify behavior on timescales both long (years) and short (minutes-hrs). Two eruptions have been partially documented since 1998 but measurements of the pre-eruption inflation period are not complete. Since Axial is in what is interpreted to be the re-inflation stage now, following a 2011 eruption, the opportunity to complete characterization of the cycle exists. This geodetic fieldwork will take place in 2015 and 2017, with student participation and provision of seafloor imagery for use in Science on a Sphere exhibits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Levy et al. (2018) used seismic data from the 2015 eruption to estimate co-eruption dip-slip motion along the eastern edge of an outward-dipping caldera ring fault. This ring fault motion complicates the deformation field and may contribute up to several centimeters of vertical motion in some locations. We incorporated these fault deformation estimates into our volcano deformation models by calculating the co-eruption fault-induced deformation and removing it from vertical seafloor deformation data prior to volcano source inversions. The resulting deformation source model inversions improve the model fit of three independent data sets of varying temporal and spatial resolution for the 2015 eruption period. The incorporation of co-eruption fault motion in model inversions of 2013-2015 Mobile Pressure Recorder (MPR) data resulted in a new best-fitting deformation source for the 2015 eruption?a steeply dipping prolate spheroid with a depth to center of 3.08 km located 2.32 km S64?W of the best-fit source of Nooner and Chadwick (2016). The newly derived 2015 eruption deformation source with fault deformation removed is closer to the center of the caldera, the region of magma replenishment interpreted from seismic surveys, and agrees with magmatic source depths from geochemical and seismic studies. This improved source model indicates that fault motion significantly impacts observed deformation at Axial Seamount and that future geodetic source models should include fault motion to provide better estimates of active magma movement through time at Axial Seamount. This study is described in detail by Hefner et al. (2020).

We have also used the post-eruption deformation data from Bottom Pressure Recorders (BPRs) to identify small-scale deviations from the long-term re-inflation signal. We identify these anomalies using a differential uplift technique, where noise that is coherent over a large area is removed by subtracting the pressure time series from a stable reference BPR from all of the other BPRs in our network. Any remaining deviations from a linear uplift trend that are consistently seen in the BPR network are interpreted as variations in the magma dynamics of the system. This has allowed, for the first time, periods of anomalous deformation within the overall inflation signal to be discernable. The largest anomaly that we have identified occurs over a 29-day period from the 2017-2018 inter-eruption period at Axial Seamount and has a maximum amplitude of several millimeters. The timing and duration of the anomaly is slightly different for each of the BPRs which suggests complexity in the magmatic system that requires a complex mechanism, such as a combination of magma movement and slip along a fault, to explain.
